title: The Dennis and Mireille Gillings Global Public Health Fellowship
text:
Research Associate (G7), Senior Research Associate (SRA) (G9)* or Clinical Research Associate (CRA) 
G7 - £28,695 - £37,394, G9 - £38,511 - £48,743, CRA - £31,301 - £54,199 
The Dennis and Mireille Gillings Global Public Health Fellowship is a collaboration between the University of Cambridge (Autism Research Centre (ARC) and the Cambridge Institute of Public Health (CIPH)); the Institut Pasteur (Unité de Génétique Humaine et fonctions cognitives and Autism Genetics Lab); and Peking University (Centre for BioInformatics and Autism Genetics). This Fellowship is an exciting opportunity for an excellent candidate with a background in Public Health or a related discipline to become a future leader in Public Health, shaping health and science policy in relation to Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). 
This unique Fellowship will include a training programme that is tailored to equip the Gillings Fellow with leadership skills and business entrepreneurship, against a backdrop of research excellence, providing a clear pathway for early career researchers toward leadership roles in global public health. The Fellowship will be focused on public health research addressing the complex ethical, economical, and social issues needed for the successful translation of genetic findings into clinical, individual, or governmental policy and practice. The Fellowship will last for three years and include substantial periods in international locations, such laboratories of the Institut Pasteur International Network and at Peking University in China. The focus of the Gillings Fellow's research will be collaborative projects between Cambridge and the Institut Pasteur and will expose the Fellows to a range of disciplines. In addition, the Gillings Fellow will receive public health leadership skills training during the first year of the Fellowship and take the Postgraduate Diploma in Entrepreneurship at the Judge Business School in Cambridge during year two of the Gillings Fellowship. 
Candidates must hold a PhD (ideally related to a health science, but does not have to be) and must hold a Master's degree in Public Health, epidemiology, or a related health science. Clinical candidates can hold higher medical degree (e.g. a doctorate) instead of a PhD, but must also hold a Master's degree in Public Health, epidemiology, or a related health science. Candidates for Clinical Research Associate grade must hold a full GMC registration with a license to practice. If the successful candidate is appointed as a Clinical Research Associate they must have an Honorary Contract with Public Health England. Candidates with a PhD must hold a PhD degree at the start of the fellowship (but not necessarily at the time of application). 
The main place of work will be the Institute of Public Health, University of Cambridge, Forvie Site, Robinson Way, Cambridge Biomedical Campus Cambridge, CB2 0SR. 
Limit of Tenure - Available to start in January 2016 for 3 years 
To apply online for this vacancy and to view further information about the role, please visit the apply link and this will take you to the role on the University’s Job Opportunities pages. There you will need to click on the 'Apply online' button and register an account with the University's Web Recruitment System (if you have not already) and log in before completing the online application form. 
For an informal discussion about the post, please contact Professor Carol Brayne, Director Cambridge Institute of Public Health, University of Cambridge e-mail cb105@medschl.cam.ac.uk 
Interview Date: 5th November 2015 at the Cambridge Institute of Public Health. 
*NB: The status of SRA is awarded on the basis of individual merit and may be awarded to the successful candidate if approved by the Faculty Board of the Cambridge School of Clinical Medicine 
Please quote reference SY06985 on your application and in any correspondence about this vacancy.
